em condições ambientalmente seguras este resíduo (MOTA; FILHO; BARRETO, 2019) . Consequentemente , os autores projetaram uma unidade portátil e acessível de produ ção de biodiesel para as pequenas comunid ades pesqueiras (MOTA; FILHO; BARRETO, No caso do lodo de esgoto, para ajudar a acelerar a produção em larga escala de biodiesel, a cadeia de abastecimento precisa ser projetada e otimizada, desde o fornecimento de lodo até a distribuição de biodi esel para as zonas de demanda (MOHSENI; PISHVAEE, 2020) . A escassez de dados para um planejamento estratégico da cadeia de abastecimento limita a aplicabilidade de algumas modelagens propostas na literatura para a realidade (ATABANI et al., 2019a; GUPTA; RATHOD, 2018b; MOHSENI; PISHVAEE, 2020; MOTA; FILHO; BARRETO, 2019) .

Além da referida escassez, a falta de integração entre divers as partes interessadas torna a coleta correta de dados um desafio (HABIB et al., 2021) . Como cada município é responsável pelo manejo dos resíduos sólidos urbanos, a estrutura descentralizada desponta como um dos maiores desafios, pois cerca de 70% dos municípios brasileiros têm menos de 20 mil habitantes, que inviabiliza a sustentabilidade de alguns serviços (BRASIL, 2021c) . Ademais, os municípios de menor porte também enfrentam dificuldades para uma gestão eficiente e manejo de resíduos sólidos urbanos (KNOPF, O transporte tem uma grande importância dentro da cadeia de suprimento. Dependendo da locali zação dos produtores, cooperativas, fábricas de processamento e da planta de biodiesel, o custo de transporte pode compromete r o fornecimento da MPR (CÉSAR et al., 2017a; CHÁVEZ; SARACHE; COSTA, 2018; GANEV et al., 2021) . No caso do Brasil , segundo a Confederação Nacional de Transportes (CNT) , o sistema rodoviário é responsável por 61,1% de toda a carga transportada no país. À vista disso, os altos preços de combustível também são responsáveis muitas vezes por inviabilizar a coleta das MPR (GUABIROBA et al., 2017) .

Outros d esafios no transporte da MPR estão relacionados aos riscos operacionais . Insuasty -Reina , Tascon -Rueda e Osorio -Gomez (2022) levantaram 25 pontos relacionados ao transporte de WCO entre e les: problemas no veículo do transporte ; atrasos na coleta devido a eventos externos ; estradas em mau estado ; capacidade limitada de carga do veículo na coleta e transporte ; e problemas associados a comunicação com o transportador . Estes riscos foram ident ificados e distribuídos em uma matriz de
probabilidade de impacto dos riscos , que gerou o ranking de prioridade de risco presente na Figura 23 (INSUASTY -REINA; TASCÓN -RUEDA; OSORIO -GÓMEZ, 2022) .

Fonte: Adaptado de INSUASTY -REINA; TASCÓN -RUEDA; OSORIO -GÓMEZ, 2022 . Outro fator importante é que o transporte de cargas é um dos principais contribuintes para a emissão de GEE (DUARTE; SARACHE; COSTA, 2016; MARUFUZZAMAN; EKŞIOĞLU; HERNANDEZ, 2015) . Com isso, as novas tendências de pesquisa visam alcançar um equilíbrio justo entre a rentabilidade d a cadeia de suprimento e a sustentabilidade ambiental (DUARTE; SARACHE; COSTA, 2016) . Para tal, Karme (2018) propôs a coordenação dos atores da cadeia com o objetivo de reduzir os custos logísticos. Em um sistema de logística reversa, o produtor do resíduo se torna o responsável pelo descarte do mesmo. Sendo assim, semelhante à coleta de cartuchos de impressora , a coleta poderia ocorrer através de um serviço de pacotes para resíduos dispersos, como é o caso o WCO e da borra de café (KARMEE, 2018) . No que t ange as condições e capacidade de armazenamento e coleta, devido à natureza dos resíduos, algumas considerações devem ser feitas. O processo de armazenamento e coleta apresentam alguns riscos operacionais possíveis como f alta de espaço de armazenamento ; derramamento ou vazamentos d urante o processo; i ncêndio ; contaminação d evido a a rmazenamento impróprio ; ou d eterioração de tanques de Rodovias em condições ruins Problemas mecânicos no veículo Derramamento de WCO Não conformidade no transporte terceirizad o Falta de combustível no veículo Criminalidade Vazamento do WCO Imprudência do motorista Acidente de trânsito Não conformidade com as regras de transporte Manuseio impróprio Violação das regras de trânsito Distribuição inadequada de containers no veículo Problemas de documentação do veículo Aumento no custo do combustí vel Congestionamento do trânsito
armazenamento ou coleta (ALAJMI et al., 2018; CHÁVEZ; SARACHE; COSTA, 2018; INSUASTY -REINA; TASCÓN -RUEDA; OSORIO -GÓMEZ, 2022 ; JIANG; ZHANG, 2016; MOHSENI; PISHVAEE, 2020) .

Existem oportunidades para melhorias nos procedimentos de boas práticas de manuseio, transporte e armazenamento fora da usina, especialmente os conduzidos pela distribuição (ANP, 2021b) . Insuasty -Reina , Tascon -Rueda e Osorio -Gomez (2022) também levantaram os riscos associados a coleta e armazenamento de WCO. A m atriz de probabilidade de impacto dos riscos discutida pelos autores gerou o r anking de prioridade de risco presente na Figura 2 4.

Fonte: INSUASTY -REINA; TASCÓN -RUEDA; OSORIO -GÓMEZ, 2022 . A qualidade e a estabilidade do suprimento a longo prazo são fatores importantes para que a MPR seja considerada viável para a produção de biodiesel (KUMARAN et al., 2011) .Avinash , Sasikumar e Murugesan (2018) identificaram a inconsistência na quantidade fornecida como uma das principais barreiras para a implementação do WCO em larga escala . APÊNDICE B – ARTIGO PARA SUBMISSÃO

MAPPING OPPORTUNITIES AND CHALLENGES IN THE USE OF WASTE AS FEEDSTOCK FOR BIODIESEL PRODUCTION IN BRAZIL Nayara Couto Ezequiel de Araujo 1, Fabio de A. Oroski, Flavia C. Alves. 1Department of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemistry, University of Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), Rio de Janeiro, 21941 -972, Brazil. (nayara.couto@eq.ufrj.br)
Abstract:

In 2021, the use of biodiesel avoided the emission of 19 megatons of carbon dioxide gas in Brazil (EPE, 2022). Biodiesel feedstocks represent a major challenge to the competitiveness of biodi esel towards diesel, because at least 80% of the total costs associated with its production is related to feedstock (ELGHARBAWY et al. , 2021). Therefore, this cost can be reduced by 30 -40% by using residual raw materials (HAJJARI et al. , 2017). Using a sys tematic literature review (SLR), this study explores the technological and non -technological barriers to the use of waste as feedstock for biodiesel production in Brazil. In what concerns technological barriers, the results reveal the search for improvemen ts in processing technologies or catalysts to improve conversion yield. In terms of non -technological barriers, public authorities play a large role as facilitators in the introduction of residual feedstocks. The challenges related to the supply chain show the importance of investment in research and development, especially in scaling up. Keywords: biodiesel; bioeconomy; waste feedstock; waste -derived fuel; food waste; renewable raw material.
1. Introduction

Society has been aware of the environmental impacts caused by the use of fossil feedstocks, such as the emission of greenhouse gases (YAQOOB, 2021). In 2021, almost 200 countries at the United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP26) recognized the emergency of reducing carbon emissions. A large number of countries are officially beginning a shift towards a more sustainable world. India, China, EU, Brazil and the United States have formalized their pledges to reach net zero or carbon neutrality between 2030 and 2070 (UNDP, 2022). Among the sectors responsi ble for carbon emissions,

transport presents the greatest difficulty in meeting targets, mainly due to the extensive use of fossil fuels (MCDONAGH et al. , 2019). Approximately 28% of all energy generated in the world is consumed by this sector, with biofue ls representing only 3% (MATHEW et al. , 2021). In the Brazilian context, in 2021 biofuels accounted for 22.6% of all energy used in the transport sector (MME, 2021). Due to the mandatory use of biodiesel in diesel oil, in 2021 Brazil avoided the emission o f 19 megatons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere (EPE, 2022). An interesting source of opportunity lies in helping the transition from fossil fuels to renewable fuels.

The sustainability of a raw material is defined by its availability, positive impact on GHG emissions and minimization of the negative impact on biodiversity and land use (LEE; SHAH, 2013). According to data from ANP's 2022 yearbook, with regard to the raw materials used in 2021 in the production of biodiesel in Brazil, soybean accounted f or 72.1% of the total (EPE, 2022). For large -scale agricultural production, indiscriminate land use causes GHG emissions, in addition to extensive water use and other adverse impacts on biodiversity (CABRERA -JIMÉNEZ et al. , 2022; DUMORTIER; CARRIQUIRY; ELO BEID, 2021). These impacts affect the sustainability of first - generation biofuel feedstocks, such as soybean (DUMORTIER; CARRIQUIRY; ELOBEID, 2021).

In 2021, at the World Bioeconomy Forum, the former Minister of Environment in Brazil, Izabella Teixeira, st ated that "certainly, bioeconomy and circular economy are strategic algorithms for Brazil's development" (APROBIO, 2021). According to Bugge et al. (2019), research focused on bioeconomy and circular economy has been gaining prominence in recent years and spreading in many scientific fields, with the category of "Energy and Fuels" in the second most prominent position. Aiming to reduce dependence on fossil resources, the bioeconomy promotes sustainable production from the intelligent use of renewable resour ces, including the use of waste in products with higher added value (BUGGE; HANSEN; KLITKOU, 2019).

In Brazil, the need to diversify the inputs used in biodiesel production has motivated several researches to seek alternative feedstocks, such as waste (DA S; VARANASI, 2019; EPE, 2022). Waste is a plausible alternative to be explored, benefiting both the environment and society as a whole (EMBRAPA, 2014). Approximately one million tons

of bovine tallow ceased to be an environmental liability to be used in th e production of biodiesel. This input represents the second most used isolated feedstock, followed by pork fat and other fat materials (both with approximately 600 thousand tons) (EPE, 2022). Other second -generation feedstocks, such as industrial, agricult ural and municipal solid waste show great potential to reduce carbon emissions (DAS; VARANASI, 2019). However, the intensive use of residual feedstocks still presents technological and non - technological barriers that will be discussed in this paper.

In thi s context, it is important to identify the technological and non -technological bottlenecks for the use of waste for biodiesel production in Brazil. To this end, the specific objectives of the work are to map the potential residues for the production of bio diesel in Brazil; to define the criteria for the identification of opportunities for the production of biodiesel from the identified residues; and finally, to characterise the technological bottlenecks (barriers in the extraction of oil, challenges in the pre-treatment stage, degree of technological maturity, efficiency in conversion, problems of biodiesel purification, among others) and non -technological bottlenecks (logistics of access to the residues, structuring of production chains, actors involved, am ong others). In order to answer these questions, this paper is structured in four sections, besides this introduction. Section 2 refers to the methodology developed for the pre -prospecting and systematic search stage for mapping articles related to the use of waste in biodiesel production. Section 3 discusses theoretical concepts covering the topics of biodiesel, as well as the main challenges to structure opportunities in the context of bioeconomy and waste for biodiesel production. Section 4 presents a co mparative discussion about the results. Finally, section 5 presents the conclusions about this study.
2. Methodology

To mitigate climate change caused by greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, a global effort is taking place to develop renewable and sustainable ene rgy (MMA, 2021). The methodology adopted in this research aims to investigate the technological and non - technological bottlenecks faced by the different residual feedstocks for biodiesel production. Bottlenecks are defined in this dissertation as the barri ers that each feedstock faces to be used in biodiesel production. Technological bottlenecks are the technological

barriers pertaining to the pre -treatment, conversion and post -conversion stages. In addition to these challenges, other non -technology barrier s are faced by the residual feedstocks. Non -technological bottlenecks comprise legal, market and logistics barriers such as government policies, subsidies, consumer confidence, logistics operation and supply chain. In this research, to establish the criter ia to be defined in the systematic search for non -technological bottlenecks, the focus was established on the logistics and supply process for each residual raw material, not limiting itself to these alone. The definition of strategies for the prospective analysis is a fundamental step in the process of search, selection and analysis of documents. With this, the methodology employed was divided into two levels of analysis:

i. Pre-prospecting: Information from documents is analysed systematically, but with a restricted selection of documents to be evaluated. The objective of this stage is to define the raw materials to be analysed in this research, as well as the criteria to be applied in the forced systematic search; ii. Systematic search: With the information obtained during the pre -prospecting stage, a systematic search was conducted from the selected raw materials. In general, both searches were performed in the Web of Science database and follow the criteria shown in Fig. 1.

2.1.Pre-prospecting

The pre -prospecting stage employed in this research used information from scientific articles in the Web of Science (WoS) database. The objective of this stage was to define the raw materials to be used in the forced search. Among the types of scientific articles, reviews are distinguished by being prepared through an extensive source of literature (NASSI -CALÒ, 2021). In view of this, the reviews were selected t o capture more broadly the research related to biodiesel production.

The pre -prospecting stages of this work are illustrated in Fig. 2. In general, three WoS searches were conducted. Subsequently, the selected documents went through a selection process. At the end of the process occurred the full reading of the documents within the scope of work for the selection of raw materials to be used in the forced systematic search. Figure 2 - Overview of the stages of pre -prospecting for the definition of the select ed feedstocks.
Source: Own elaboration.

In this exploratory search the 50 most relevant reviews in each of the three searches were selected, totaling 150 reviews. The screening of these documents occurred with the inclusion or exclusion of articles accor ding to defined criteria. Papers outside the scope of the research and duplicate papers were excluded during the screening. After screening, 30 reviews were selected for full reading. Table 1 elucidates the 10 residual raw materials found in the reviews. T he most expressive were used frying oil (present in 13 articles), followed by animal fat (in 7 articles), sludge and wastewater (together totaling 6 articles) and organic waste (in 6 articles). Spent ground coffee were

selected as organic waste for the sys tematic search. As Brazil is the world's largest coffee consumer, consequently it is also one of the largest generators of this type of waste. Each ton of raw coffee releases approximately half a ton of coffee grounds, which is the main post-consumption wa ste (DURÁN et al. , 2017). Thus, this waste is in line with the scope of the research that is focused on raw materials in the Brazilian case. In summary, the four raw materials selected for the systematic search were waste cooking oil, animal fat, sludge/wa stewater and spent coffee grounds. 2.2.Systematic search
a. Technological bottlenecks Regarding technological bottlenecks, the forced systematic search started with the following criteria:

- Documents published between 01 January 2016 and 31 December 2021; - The respective raw materials as keywords in the topic field. - The keyword "Biodiesel Production" concatenated with the respective feedstock using the Boolean operato r "AND" in the topic field. - The keywords "Energy Fuels; Engineering Chemical; Biotechnology Applied Microbiology; Environmental Science; Green Sustainable Science Technology; Engineering Environmental" in the Web of Science categories field.

These criter ia resulted in 769 documents for used frying oil, 229 documents for animal fat, 85 documents for coffee grounds and 1065 documents for wastewater/sewage sludge. After applying these criteria, the results of the search were: 77 documents for waste cooking o il, 21 documents for animal fat, 50 documents for spent coffee grounds and 68 documents for wastewater/sewage sludge. These 216 documents were selected for screening and subsequent full reading and evaluation of the technological bottlenecks. b. Non-technolog ical bottlenecks Regarding non -technological bottlenecks, the systematic search started with the following criteria:

- Documents published between 01 January 2016 and 31 December 2021; - The respective raw materials as a keyword in the title field. - Keywo rd "Biodiesel Production" in the topic field; - Keyword "Supply Chain" concatenated with the keyword "Logistic*" using the Boolean operator "OR" in the topic field.

The category criterion was not used as there were no results when using this parameter in the searches. These criteria resulted in 17 documents for used frying oil, 2 documents for animal fat, 2 documents for coffee grounds and 5 documents for wastewater/sewage sludge. After the application of these criteria the results of the search were: 30 do cuments for used fried oil, 50 documents for waste water and sewage sludge, 29 documents for animal fat and 33 documents for coffee grounds. Thus, 142 documents were selected for screening and subsequent full reading and evaluation of non -technological bot tlenecks.
3. Theory
4.1.Biodiesel

The concept of biodiesel adopted by the National Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels Agency (ANP) is of a "fuel composed of alkyl esters of long -chain carboxylic acids, produced from the transesterification and or/esterification of fatty materials, of fats of vegetable or animal origin, and which meets the specification contained in Technical Over 95% of the raw material used for the production of biodiesel comes from edible oils, which represe nts above all a possible global imbalance for the food supply and demand

market (GUI; LEE; BHATIA, 2008). Moreover, biodiesel feedstocks are responsible for at least 80% of the costs associated with its production (ELGHARBAWY et al. , 2021). In 2021, soybea n oil stood out as the most important input in biodiesel production (71,2%), followed by other fat materials (11,5%) and beef tallow (8,9%) (EPE, 2022). As vegetable oil is the main feedstock, this mainly represents a possible global imbalance for the food supply and demand market (GUI; LEE; BHATIA, 2008). In addition to not competing with food production, a life cycle analysis (LCA) study of first -generation biodiesel showed that when carbon emissions related to land use change are included in the calc ulations, all varieties of first -generation biodiesel had a higher average carbon footprint than fossil -sourced diesel. In the analysis of second -generation biodiesel, GHG emissions were 60 -90% lower than that of conventional diesel, being carbon neutral o r carbon negative (TABATABAEEI; AGHBASHLO, 2019).

Moreover, biodiesel feedstocks are mainly influenced by the feedstock price, which can represent 70 -80% of the total biodiesel production cost when using vegetable oils (ELGHARBAWY et al. , 2021). The biodie sel production cost can be reduced by 30 -40% by using residual feedstocks such as waste oils or animal fats (HAJJARI et al. , 2017). Thus, the b iodiesel can be produced from various waste materials such as animal fat, used frying oil, yellow and brown greas e, sewage sludge, process wastewater, food waste, among others (MORONE; SICA; MAKARCHUK, 2020; SHAH, 2021; SINGH et al. , Fig. 3 elucidates the flow chart for producing biodiesel from feedstock in four stages: collection, pre -treatment, production (which includes conversion and post -conversion) and distribution. With regard to residual raw materials the process of obtaining the oil differs. Pre -treatment methodologies due to the variability of biomass composition do not present a single u niversal method (YOUSUF; SANNINO; PIROZZI, 2020). All fat and waste oil should be pre -processed before being used as feedstock for maximum biodiesel yield. The pre -processing step includes separation of non -fat residues and water present, neutralization of pH and liquefaction of fat for easier handling (SRINIVASAN; JAMBULINGAM, 2018).
Figure 3 - Biodiesel production process from collection to distribution.
Source: Adapted from ZHANG et al. , 2017.

Both vegetable oil and waste oil or grease have too high viscosity to be used directly in most diesel engines (BANERJEE; RAMAKRISHNAN; JASH, 2014). There are several ways to reduce the viscosity of vegetable oils and make them suitable for use as biofuels (DEMIRBAS, 2008). To solve the problems encountered with high viscosity, the conversion technologies used are transesterification (most widely used), esterification, hybrid processes and supercritical processes (ELGHARBAWY et al. , 2021). After the conversion stage, a post -conversion, or purification stage, is a pplied for the removal of glycerol, the main by -product, and to keep the biodiesel within the specifications defined for its commercialisation (DAS; VARANASI, 2019).
4.2.Biodiesel in Brazil

Due to the vast area for agricultural production, Brazil has great pot ential to remain among the main players in the biofuels market (APROBIO, 2021). Since the beginning of PNPB in 2004 until December 2020, more than 47 billion litres of biodiesel have already been produced in Brazil (EPE, 2022). According to the Conjuncture Analysis of Biofuels published in 2022 by the MME, Brazil remains among the three largest biodiesels producing and consuming countries in the international ranking (EPE, 2022). In January 2008, the legally mandatory mixture of 2% (B2) came into force thro ughout the national territory, evolving to 5% as of 2013. In December 2016, it was approved by the National Energy Policy Council (CNPE) to increase the percentage from 7% to 8% in the mixture in March 2017 and increasing to 10% at the end of 2018 accordin g to Law No. 13.263/2016. The ANP approved in August 2019 the increase of the biodiesel mixture

from 10% to 11% in diesel oil, as of September 1, after new tests showed satisfactory from studies made by the National Institute of Technology (INT). This valu e reached 12% in March 2020, as provided in CNPE Resolution n°16/2018 (CNPE, 2018). After this law, CNPE Resolution n°16/2018 proposed a schedule with a gradual increase of 1 percentage point of biodiesel in the diesel mixture per year, seeking to reach 15 %, in 2023 (CNPE, As provided for in the legal framework, in March 2021 the biodiesel content in diesel reached 13% (EPE, 2022). However, due to the economic challenges faced during the Covid -19 pandemic, through CNPE Resolutions No. 4 and No. 10/2 021, the mandatory biodiesel content in diesel was reduced from 13% to 10% between May and August 2021 (CNPE, 2021a). Then, CNPE Resolution No. 11/2021 returned the mandatory biodiesel content to 12%, the same content instituted in 2020 (CNPE, 2021b). In N ovember 2021, as a measure to contain diesel prices, the CNPE decided to maintain the 10% biodiesel content in diesel for all of 2022 (ANP, 2021).
4. Results and discussion

This section will present results obtained in this study, discussing, comparatively, the whole sample of biodiesel production from the four waste feedstocks selected: waste cooking oil, animal fat, spent coffee grounds and wastewater/sewage sludge. This section will be structured in two sections of analysis referring to tech nological and non - technological bottlenecks.
4.1.Technological bottlenecks

Initially 216 documents were selected for screening. Of these, 135 documents were excluded. For this research, the exclusion criteria used during the screening of documents were: quarti le criterion (journals belonging to the Q1 quartile); papers outside the scope of the research; and duplicate papers. At the end of the full reading, 81 articles were used. Technological bottlenecks identified during the forced systematic search are descri bed in Table 2. Information was structured and divided amongst the three stages to be evaluated: pre-treatment, conversion and purification. The second level of separation of the table corresponds to the respective technological bottlenecks within each sta ge of the first level.

The following four levels indicate the quantity of articles in each technological bottleneck per residual feedstock (RF). The evaluated publications present one or more technological bottlenecks, however not all bottlenecks were foun d for all RFs.

4.1.1. Technological bottlenecks in the pre -treatment stage

Regarding the feedstock it was identified that variation in quality, the presence of suspended solids and high free fatty acid (FFA) and water content are barriers that need attention. Janbarari & Behrooz (2020) simulated biodiesel production from used fry ing oils collected from different sources. The uncertainty in the quality of the collected oil made it difficult for the designer to define the design and operating conditions (JANBARARI; BEHROOZ, 2020). Sander et al. (2018) synthesised biodiesel from five different types of animal fat and detected that the type of feedstock as well as the presence of impurities strongly influenced the quality of biodiesel (SANDER et al. , 2018). For coffee grounds, the chemical composition depends on factors such as plant s pecies, cultivation site, plant age, climate and soil conditions (ATABANI et al. , 2022). In the analysis by Chi et al. (2018), significant differences were found in the yield and composition of lipid sludge from different types of industrial and municipal wastewater.

In this research, the different types included starch wastewater, restaurant wastewater, livestock wastewater, landfill leachate, tannery waste and sewage sludge from two different districts (CHI et al. , 2018).

The presence of high free fatty a cid (FFA) and water content is one of the major drawbacks when dealing with waste feedstocks (ABOELAZAYEM; GADALLA; SAHA, 2018). The high level of FFA accelerates some unwanted side reactions, reducing the conversion rate (PUGAZHENDHI et al. , 2020; SADAF et al., 2018). Moreover, high FFA and water content lead to soap formation during alkaline catalytic transesterification (KATRE et al. , 2018). In the case of coffee grounds, the high acidity makes the conversion into biodiesel economically unviable (ATABANI et al. , 2019). In summary, it is understood that pre -treatment is an essential step before oil processing for conversion into biodiesel (MATHEW et al. , 2021). For the use of residual feedstocks (RFs), efficient methods are required to extract the oil or as in the case of WCO, to make it suitable for the transesterification step (KARMEE, 2018; SADAF et al. , 2018).
4.1.2. Technological bottlenecks in the convers ion stage

Factors such as conversion technology, catalyst, alcohol content, temperature and time were pointed out as barriers during the conversion step. Approximately 70% of the papers point out that process conditions are critical for process viability. Biodiesel obtained from waste feedstocks presents some technical challenges to achieve economic viability (SINGH et al. , 2021). Besides more efficient and low -cost pre -treatment processes, these challenges include modifications in current technologies for higher quality production and the development of better and cheaper catalysts (MATHEW et al. , 2021). In the conversion process, it is essential to seek more cost -efficient technologies for commercial viability of biodiesel production (HABIB et al. , 2020). The predominant technology in the residual feedstocks was catalytic transesterification, preceded or not by an esterification step. Since it is a technology already widely used and disseminated, most authors sought to optimize the operational parameters (I SHAK; KAMARI, 2019). This optimization path occurs since, changing the technology could represent a high implementation cost (HABIB et al. , 2021). However, for waste feedstocks with high water content (such as wastewater and sewage sludge) in situ transest erification has been

explored (HU et al. , 2020). Present in 50% of the articles, in situ transesterification uses a smaller amount of solvent and energy to achieve the required yield in a reduced reaction time (KATRE et al. , 2018). Another relevant factor of this technology is the decrease in costs by not performing the drying step, besides being a simpler process in a single step (HU et al. , 2020). Supercritical transesterification has been explored, but the economic feasibility remains a challenge (ABOELA ZAYEM; GADALLA; SAHA, 2018a).

The search for more efficient and lower cost catalysts was reported in 67% of the surveyed papers and the types of catalysts discussed are showing in Fig. 4. Industrially, transesterification with basic homogeneous catalysts i s the most common process because it is simpler and faster (ELGHARBAWY et al. , 2021). This type of catalyst has some disadvantages, among them the non -reusable nature and the sensitivity to the presence of FFA in the oil, and saponification may occur (TALH A; SULAIMAN, 2016; YAASHIKAA; KUMAR; KARISHMA, 2022). In recent years, the development of heterogeneous catalysts has been gaining prominence. This type of catalyst presents interesting properties, such as simpler recovery and possibility of reuse (BORAH et al., 2019). During the research, 53% of the papers used heterogeneous catalysts, with emphasis on the use of metal salts and residual heterogeneous catalysts. In the case of residual heterogeneous catalysts, eggshells were used (BORAH et al. , 2019; GUPTA ; RATHOD, 2018; PUTRA et al. , 2018) and animal bones, such as chicken and ostrich (KHAN et al. , 2020; ZIK; SULAIMAN; JAMAL, 2020). Biodiesel production with residual catalysts besides being cleaner, can obtain biodiesel at a considerably reduced final cos t (PUTRA et al. , 2018). In the in situ process was reported for coffee grounds, co-solvents such as DBU (1,8 -diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec -7-ene) and DCE (1,2 - dichloroethane) acted as catalyst during the transesterification process (NGUYEN et al. , Figure 4 - Types of catalysts discussed in the articles.

Source: Own elaboration based on data from Web Of Science. Alcohol content is another important factor in biodiesel production. The stoichiometric molar ratio is 3 mols of alcoho l for each mol of triglyceride in the transesterification reaction (MATHEW et al. , 2021). However, to shift the equilibrium to the product side, an excess of alcohol is commonly applied. Alcohol contents between 6:1 (EL SHIMI; MOUSTAFA, 2018; GARCÍA -MARTÍN et al. , 2018) and 20:1 (BORAH et al. , 2019; HU et al. , 2020) have been found for transesterification processes with homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts.

Finally, another experimental condition influencing the conversion of RFs into biodiesel is temperature (ALAJMI et al. , 2018; JUNIOR et al. , 2020; PUGAZHENDHI et al. , 2020; SON et al. , 2018). The transesterification reaction is an endothermic reaction, so to overcome the energy barrier, an adequate amount of energy in the form of heat is required (GUPTA; RATHOD, 2018). In wastewater the temperature range varied greatly. In in situ transesterification, the optimal temperature used varied from 28°C to 160°C ( ZHANG et al. , In addition to the experimental conditions mentioned above, the reaction time was also an important factor during conversion. Reaction time affects conversion and is directly linked to the type of conversion technology and the type of catalyst employed. Tr aditionally, conversion into biodiesel is carried out through the transesterification reaction. One of the widely known problems in catalytic transesterification is that the processes are relatively time consuming and require separation of the mixture of o il, alcohol, catalyst and impurities from biodiesel (BASKAR et al. , 2019). Thus, some researches have used the assisted transesterification 024681012141618202224262830Homogeneous e HeterogeneousWithout catalystEnzimaticHomogeneousHeterogeneous Heterogeneous Residual heterogeneous catalyst Basic homogeneous catalyst Acid homogeneous catalyst Enzimatic Without catalyst Homogeneous e Heterogeneous
technique to reduce the operation time, energy requirement and improve the efficiency (ALAJMI et al. , 2018).
4.1.3. Techno logical bottlenecks in post -conversion

After conversion, the barriers identified were the presence of properties outside the required standards and difficulty in the purification process. The most reported problems in the physicochemical properties of biod iesel from waste feedstock were: high cetane number, high viscosity, low flash point and high acid value (EL SHIMI; MOUSTAFA, 2018; GÜLÜM; YESILYURT; BILGIN, 2019; MARELLA et al. , 2019).

Regarding purification, less than 10% of the articles reported the ch allenges present in this step. Pollardo et al. (2017), Putra et al. (2018) and Aboelazayem, Gadalla and Saha (2018) discussed the difficulty in separating biodiesel produced from residual feedstocks from by - products. On commercial scale, biodiesel is mostl y produced using basic homogeneous catalysts such as NaOH and KOH. Consequently, the purification step becomes more expensive due to the complexity in the process of separating the catalyst from the produced biodiesel (LIU et al. , 2021; POLLARDO et al. , 2017; PUTRA et al. , 2018). Membrane separation is new in biodiesel production and recent studies have revealed the promising capability of this technology in increasing process efficiency (BANSOD et al. , 2021; ENNACERI et al. , 2022; SHI et al. , 2022). Howeve r, the performance and economical aspects of membrane systems on an industrial scale still need to be examined (ATABANI et al. , 2019).
4.2.Non-technological bottlenecks

For the non -technological bottlenecks 142 documents were selected. During the full reading, 91 documents were excluded. The exclusion criteria used during the screening of the documents were: Papers outside the scope of the research and duplicate articles. In this way, 51 documents were used in the research.

The lower volume of articles identifi ed suggests that there is either low interest in the non - technological barriers of residual raw materials or that the criteria used for the selection of documents were not the most appropriate. The difficulty in finding information outside the technologica l context has been observed since the pre -prospecting stage. In this research, for the non -technological barriers the focus was on the logistics and supply process of the residual

feedstock (RF). However, the analysis was not restricted to these aspects al one. The non - technological bottlenecks encountered were divided into four groups and are described in Fig. 5 with the bottleneck distinctions between the RFs.

To achieve this, there is a 3345822122810 024681012141618202224Restricted/reduced marketLack of awareness of the populationFailing penalties for incorrect disposal of RFUncertainty in demand and price of RFLack of government subsidies/policiesEconomic feasibility / High operating costLack of R&D on larger scalesCollection and storage conditions and capacityLack of long-term supply stabilityLack of data for strategic planningAbsence or unavailability of the supply chainChallenges in transporting RF from source to industryOthers Public willEconomic viability Supply chain WCO Animal Fat Spent Ground Coffee Wastewater / Sludge

need to go beyond the simple use of raw materials and alternative technologies, and introduce innovations at all levels of the various supply chains that affect the system as a whole (JANDER; GRUNDMANN, 2019). However, the use of waste as a raw material presents several challenges within the supply chain (DUARTE; SARACHE; COSTA, 2016; HABIB et al. , 2020; JIANG; ZHANG, 2016; KWON; KIM; HAN, 2022; MARUFUZZAMAN; EKŞIOĞLU; HERNANDEZ, 2014). Careful logistics planning is essential for a well - functioning supply chain, decreasing distribution time and costs (MIRANDA et al. , 2018). Determining the location of the biorefinery and the amount of biodiesel to be produced, transported or used assists in reducing the total cost of the supply chain project for the biodiesel industry based on residual feedstocks (KWON; KIM; HAN, 2022). Barriers such as the absence or unavailability of supply chain, challenges faced in transporting RFs, lack of long-term supply stability, and storage conditions and capacity of RFs make logistics operation the main non -technological barrier of RFs.

With regard to the supp ly chain, RFs have different behaviours. For substitution of traditional feedstocks, cooperatives are essential within the chain (GUABIROBA et al. , 2017). Cooperatives are needed to aggregate the volume of waste generated by small producers, usually domest ic (CÉSAR et al. , 2017). For animal fat and wastewater, on the other hand, the issue does not revolve around the dispersion of RFs, but rather the absence or unavailability of the supply chain (MOHSENI; PISHVAEE, 2020; MOTA; FILHO; BARRETO, 2019). The scarcity of data for a strategic supply chain planning limits the applicability of some modelling proposed in the literature to reality (ATABANI et al. , 2019; GUPTA; RATHOD, 2018; MOHSENI; PISHVAEE, 2020; MOTA; FILHO; BARRETO, 2019). Besides the said scarcity, the lack of integration among various stakeholders makes the correct collection of data a challenge (HABIB et al. , 2021). As each municipality is responsible for the management of urban solid waste, the decentralized structure emerges as one of the bigges t challenges, since about 70% of Brazilian municipalities have less than 20 thousand inhabitants, which makes the sustainability of some services unfeasible (BRASIL, 2021). Furthermore, smaller municipalities also face difficulties in the efficient managem ent of urban solid waste (KNOPF, 2021).

Transport is of great importance within the supply chain. Depending on the location of producers, cooperatives, processing plants and the biodiesel plant, the cost of transportation can compromise the supply of RF (C ÉSAR et al. , 2017; CHÁVEZ; SARACHE; COSTA,

2018; GANEV et al. , 2021). In the case of Brazil, according to the National Transport Confederation (CNT), the road system is responsible for 61.1% of all cargo transported in the country. In view of this, high fu el prices are also often responsible for making residual feedstock collection unviable (GUABIROBA et al. , 2017).

Regarding the conditions and capacity of storage and collection, due to the nature of the waste, some considerations should be made. The storage and collection process present some possible operational risks such as lack of storage space; spillage or leaka ge during the process; fire; contamination due to improper storage; or deterioration of storage or collection tanks (ALAJMI et al. , 2018; CHÁVEZ; SARACHE; COSTA, 2018; INSUASTY -REINA; TASCÓN -RUEDA; OSORIO -GÓMEZ, 2022; JIANG; ZHANG, 2016; MOHSENI; PISHVAEE, 2020). Opportunities exist for improvements in good practice procedures for off - plant handling, transport and storage, especially those conducted by distribution (ANP, 2021). Quality and long -term supply stability are important factors for RF to be consid ered viable for biodiesel production (KUMARAN et al. , 2011).
4.2.2. Non-technological bottlenecks related to economic viability

Although the use of residual feedstocks (RFs) for biodiesel production is at bench scale, some researchers have developed plants at lar ger scales (ALAJMI et al. , 2018; IDOWU et al. , 2019). To exploit the immense potential offered by these RFs, there is a need to invest in R&D for scale -up. These studies will provide important scientific information on operational conditions and large -scale feasibility (KARMEE, 2018). In an initiative for large -scale application, Marella et al. (2019) produced biodiesel at pilot scale from microalgae dispersed in urban wastewater. The authors reported that further research is needed to make this approach mo re feasible and effective (MARELLA et al. , 2019). Large -scale production using wastewater has not yet been achieved due to high operational costs, energy intensity, as well as low algal biomass yields (ROSLI et al. , 2020). Current studies are not yet suffi cient to validate the large -scale production of biofuels from RFs such as coffee grounds and wastewater (KARMEE, 2018; LIU et al. , 2021). In addition, future studies need to combine processes within the biorefinery concept to add higher value -added product s and make the biodiesel production system feasible (MOTA; COSTA; BARRETO, 2019; SOUSA; SEABRA; NOGUEIRA, 2018).

Uncertainty in demand is highly associated with fluctuations in changes in crude oil prices and mandatory consumption policies (CÉSAR et al. , 2017; HABIB et al. , 2021; MOHSENI; PISHVAEE, 2020). Uncertainty in the price of RF is a challenge mainly affected by the cost of collection (CÉSAR et al. , 2017). It is worth noting that the price of bovine tallow was initially related to the quotation of th e ox arroba. However, after the participation of this input in biodiesel production, the dynamics of the quotation started to vary with the soybean quotation (MARTINS et al. , 2011).
4.2.3. Non-technological bottlenecks related to political will

Another non -techno logical challenge addressed in the four residual feedstocks is related to public authorities. Initiated in 2005, the National Programme for Biodiesel Production and Use (PNPB) seeks the implementation of a sustainable way to produce and use biodiesel in Brazil (BRASIL, 2022a). This federal government program focuses on social inclusion and regional development (MME, 2022). Among the main guidelines, Law No. 11,097/2005 established the mandatory blend of biodiesel with fossil diesel, with a rapid evolution o ver the years. In 2008, the value was set at 2% evolving gradually with forecast to 13% during 2021, according to Resolution CNPE n°16/2018 (EPE, 2022). However, due to economic challenges faced during the pandemic, CNPE Resolutions n°4, n°10 and n°11 and n°25 of 2021 varied the percentage of biodiesel (CNPE, 2021c). For the year 2022, CNPE Resolution No. 25 of 2021 established 10% as the mandatory biodiesel mixture content in fossil diesel oil (CNPE, 2021d). The obligation generates a demand for biodiesel, generating windows of opportunity for the expansion or reduction of this biofuel depending on the government's decisions. One of the challenges faced by residual feedstocks (RF) is the fact that they do not benefit from tax incentives and exemptions of th e Social Fuel Seal (SFS) (PADULA et al. , 2012). The SCS grants the biodiesel producer a reduction in the PIS/Pasep and COFINS tax rates for biodiesel, varying with the raw material acquired and region of acquisition (BRASIL, 2019). In addition, some polici es, such as special credits for waste -sourced biodiesel, can be introduced to encourage the use of RFs (LIU et al. , 2021). With regard to waste management, both the regulatory framework and policy actions should occur in a stakeholder -oriented manner to pr omote the necessary changes (XIONG et al. , 2019).
Specifically, for used frying oil, there is inconsistency regarding the regulation of the disposal of this waste, in addition to the absence of effective penalties for incorrect disposal.

Restaurants hardly need to worry about the risk of being supervised, as the supervision happens through denunciations in Brazil (CÉSAR et al. , 2017; ZHANG et al. , 2017a). Even if restaurants are punished, the fine is acceptable, there is not a rigorousness as in the USA and Japan, where punishments are more severe and can lead to the banning of the restaurant (ZHANG et al. , 2017a). The Senate Bill (PLS 75/2017) sought to amend the National Solid Waste Policy Law (Law 12.305/2010) to include cooking oils and fats in the rever se logistics system (SENADO, 2018). However, the bill was shelved in 2018 at the end of the legislature. A new attempt occurred in 2019, however without success and the bill remains shelved The absence of carbon regulation policies has been pointed out as one of the barriers concerning pubic power (HABIB et al. , 2020; MARUFUZZAMAN; EKŞIOĞLU; HERNANDEZ, 2014). In force since 2009, the Law of the National Policy on Climate Change - PNMC (Law 12.187/2009) aims at the consolidation of a low carb on economy to reduce GHG emissions as a result of human activity (BRASIL, 2010). However, only in May 2022 the federal government published Decree No. 11.075, which determines the procedures for the preparation of Sectoral Plans for Mitigation of Climate C hange and establishes the National System for the Reduction of Greenhouse Gas Emissions (BRASIL, 2022b). This decree regulates the carbon market in Brazil and also deals with the emission of greenhouse gases (BRASIL, 2022c). The eligible sectors for the GH G emission reduction plan will have 180 days, extendable for another 180, to present the proposals (BRASIL, 2022c). With the regulation of a national market, Brazil intends to export carbon credits (FAEP, 2022). With regard to biodiesel production, such ca rbon regulatory policies would impact how companies design and manage supply chains (GHANI et al. , 2018).
5. Conclusions

Comparison across the entire sample of articles related to biodiesel production from waste feedstock raises important discussions. The res ults of this systematic search about technological barriers reveal that the variables that influence the yield of the conversion process, such as: catalyst, alcohol content, reaction time and temperature have great impact on the decision of the raw materia l to be used for biodiesel production. Over 70% of the papers highlight the search for improvements in processing technologies or catalysts for improved conversion yield. In terms of non -technological barriers, most of the results pointed towards

the impor tance of government subsidies, incentives and specific regulations for in order to promote the use of residues in the biodiesel industry. Challenges in the collection, transportation and storage stages also demonstrate barriers present in the supply chain. Logistical problems, absence of a structured supply chain, risks associated with leaks and spills make logistics more challenging. Diagnosed problems highlighted the importance of investment in research and development, especially on a large scale. Regard ing dispersed feedstocks such as used frying oil and coffee grounds, the requirement for a more robust supply chain that could use the urban collection service to its advantage to centralise the collection.
